questions.text: In a case study involving the analysis of a new drug's mechanism of action, it's observed that the drug inhibits an enzyme by resembling the enzyme's natural substrate and competing for the active site. Given this mode of inhibition, how would this type of enzyme inhibition be classified?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Non-competitive inhibition: Inhibitors have no structural resemblance to the substrate.
  • • Option B. Non-competitive inhibition:
  • • no structural resemblance
  • • Option C. Feedback inhibition: The activity of the enzyme is inhibited by the product of the reaction .
  • • Option C. Feedback inhibition:
  • • inhibited by the product of the reaction
  • • Option D. Allosteric inhibition: The inhibitor is not a substrate analog.
  • • Option D. Allosteric inhibition:
  • • not a substrate analog.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor molecule resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the enzyme's active site . This type of inhibition can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate, as both the substrate and inhibitor compete for the same site on the enzyme.

  • ➤ substrate and competes
  • ➤ binding to the enzyme's active site

questions.text: During a biochemistry seminar, the discussion turns to the regulation of metabolic pathways by allosteric enzymes. These enzymes are unique because their activity can be modulated by molecules binding to sites other than the active site. Which of the following statements correctly describes a feature of allosteric enzymes?

options.label: A
options.text: Active site is the allosteric site in enzymes

options.label: B
options.text: All the allosteric enzymes possess positive cooperativity

options.label: C
options.text: Allosteric inhibitor is not a structural analogue

options.label: D
options.text: Activity of allosteric enzymes is described by Michaelis-Menten equation

questions.correct_answer: C. Allosteric inhibitor is not a structural analogue
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site to which the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds .
  • • Option A.
  • • Allosteric enzyme
  • • one catalytic site
  • • substrate binds
  • • another separate allosteric site
  • • modifier binds
  • • Option B. In most cases, a combination of both positive and negative cooperativity is observed , resulting in a sigmoid shaped curve .
  • • Option B.
  • • combination of both positive
  • • negative cooperativity is observed
  • • sigmoid shaped curve
  • • Option D. Not by Michaelis-Menten equation . Allosteric enzymes often display sigmoidal kinetics due to their regulatory mechanisms , which are not captured by the Michaelis-Menten model that assumes a hyperbolic relationship between enzyme activity and substrate concentration.
  • • Option D.
  • • Michaelis-Menten equation
  • • Allosteric enzymes
  • • display sigmoidal kinetics
  • • regulatory mechanisms
  • • not captured by the Michaelis-Menten model

The effect of an allosteric modifier is maximum at or near substrate concentration equivalent to Km. When an inhibitor binds to the allosteric site, the configuration of the catalytic site is modified such that the substrate cannot bind properly. Most allosteric enzymes possess quaternary structure and are made up of subunits , e.g. Aspartate transcarbamoylase: 6 subunits and pyruvate kinase: 4 subunits.

questions.text: While studying the regulation of metabolic pathways, a medical student comes across the concept of allosteric control, particularly its role in enzyme activity. Allosteric enzymes have unique characteristics that differentiate them from other enzymes. Which of the following statements accurately describes a property of allosteric enzymes?

options.label: A
options.text: Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites

options.label: D
options.text: Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways

questions.correct_answer: D. Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Allosteric control with negative feedback is indeed a key regulatory mechanism in many metabolic pathways, making option D correct. In negative feedback allosteric regulation, the end product of a metabolic pathway inhibits an enzyme at an earlier step in the pathway, effectively shutting down production when sufficient product has accumulated. Classic examples include:
  • • Inhibition of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) by ATP in glycolysis Inhibition of aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) by CTP in pyrimidine synthesis
  • • Inhibition of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) by ATP in glycolysis
  • • Inhibition of aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) by CTP in pyrimidine synthesis
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites : This statement is incorrect. By definition, allosteric effectors bind to sites distinct from the active site, called allosteric sites. The term "allosteric" comes from "allo" (other) and "steric" (space or structure), referring to binding at a site other than the active site. When an allosteric effector binds, it induces a conformational change that alters the activity of the enzyme.
  • • Option A. Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites
  • • Option B. Allosteric enzymes possess secondary structure : This statement is correct but not distinctive. All proteins, including enzymes (allosteric or not), possess secondary structure elements such as alpha helices and beta sheets. This is not a unique characteristic of allosteric enzymes.
  • • Option B. Allosteric enzymes possess secondary structure
  • • Option C. Allosteric control is irreversible : This is incorrect. Allosteric regulation is typically reversible, allowing for rapid adaptation to changing cellular conditions. When the concentration of the allosteric effector decreases, the enzyme can return to its original conformation and activity state.
  • • Option C. Allosteric control is irreversible

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allosteric enzymes are typically oligomeric proteins with multiple subunits that exhibit cooperativity and sigmoidal kinetics rather than the hyperbolic kinetics of Michaelis-Menten enzymes. Their activity can be modulated by effectors binding at sites distinct from the active site, causing conformational changes that alter the enzyme's catalytic efficiency. This provides a rapid, reversible mechanism for regulating metabolic pathways in response to changing cellular needs, with negative feedback being one of the most common control mechanisms in metabolism.
  • ➤ Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62.
  • ➤ Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62.

Oxidative decarboxylation: This reaction, which involves the removal of a carboxyl group and the simultaneous oxidation of the molecule , frequently depends on thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) as a coenzyme . Key metabolic pathways, including the transition from glycolysis to the citric acid cycle, involve oxidative decarboxylation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Michaelis constant (Km)?

options.label: C
options.text: Not a characteristic feature of enzymes

options.label: D
options.text: A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Substrate concentration at maximum velocity: This statement is incorrect. The substrate concentration at maximum velocity is not specifically defined by Km , as Vmax is reached at much higher substrate concentrations where all enzyme active sites are saturated.
  • • Option A. Substrate concentration at maximum velocity:
  • • substrate concentration
  • • maximum velocity
  • • not specifically defined by Km
  • • Option C. Not a characteristic feature of enzymes: This statement is incorrect. Km is indeed a characteristic feature of enzymes and is crucial in the study of enzyme kinetics.
  • • Option
  • • C. Not a characteristic feature of enzymes:
  • • Km
  • • characteristic feature of enzymes
  • • Option D. A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation: This statement is incorrect. A low Km value actually indicates a high affinity of the enzyme for its substrate, as it means the enzyme can achieve half-maximal velocity at a lower substrate concentration.
  • • Option
  • • D. A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation:
  • • low Km value
  • • high affinity of the enzyme
  • • substrate,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salient features of Km:
  • ➤ Salient features of Km:
  • ➤ Km value is substrate concentration (expressed in moles/L) at half-maximal velocity. It denotes that 50% of enzyme molecules are bound with substrate molecules at that particular substrate concentration. It is independent of enzyme concentration . It is the signature of the enzyme. Km value is thus a constant for an enzyme and it is the characteristic feature of a particular enzyme for a specific substrate. The affinity of an enzyme towards its substrate is inversely connected to the dissociation constant, Kd for the enzyme-substrate complex. Km denotes the affinity of enzymes for substrates . So, less the numerical value of Km, the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate is more.

  • ➤ It is independent of enzyme concentration .
  • ➤ independent of enzyme concentration
  • ➤ It is the signature of the enzyme. Km value is thus a constant for an enzyme and it is the characteristic feature of a particular enzyme for a specific substrate.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical research team is investigating a new drug that targets an enzyme involved in the metabolic pathway of a particular hormone. This enzyme is known for its ability to catalyze the rearrangement of atoms within the hormone molecule, effectively altering its shape without changing its chemical composition. Such a transformation is crucial for the hormone's activation and subsequent biological function. Based on the enzyme's action, which category does it belong to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Lyase: Lyases catalyze the addition or removal of groups to or from double bonds , or other formations and cleavages of double bonds through means other than hydrolysis and oxidation. They are not primarily involved in isomerization reactions.
  • • Option
  • • A. Lyase:
  • • Lyases catalyze
  • • addition or removal of groups to
  • • from double bonds
  • • formations and cleavages of double bonds
  • • hydrolysis and oxidation.
  • • Option B. Oxidoreductase: Oxidoreductases are involved in oxidation-reduction reactions , where electrons are transferred from one molecule to another . These enzymes are key players in cellular respiration and photosynthesis but do not typically catalyze structural or geometric changes within a single molecule.
  • • Option
  • • B. Oxidoreductase:
  • • oxidation-reduction reactions
  • • electrons are transferred
  • • one molecule to another
  • • enzymes
  • • cellular respiration
  • • photosynthesis
  • • Option C. Ligase: Ligases catalyze the joining of two molecules with the simultaneous hydrolysis of a diphosphate bond in ATP or a similar triphosphate . They are essential for processes like DNA replication and repair but are not responsible for isomerization.
  • • Option
  • • C. Ligase:
  • • Ligases catalyze
  • • joining of two molecules
  • • simultaneous hydrolysis
  • • diphosphate bond in ATP
  • • similar triphosphate

Hydrolases : enzymes that catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds. Lyases : enzymes that catalyze cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination , generating double bonds. Isomerases : enzymes that catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule. options.label: B
options.text: Competitive inhibitors increase the Km and have no effect on the Vmax.

options.label: C
options.text: Competitive inhibitors decrease both Km and Vmax

questions.text: In a discussion on metabolic pathways, a medical instructor emphasizes the importance of understanding how gluconeogenesis is regulated within the cell. One aspect under consideration is the spatial organization of the enzymes involved in this pathway. Is the regulation of gluconeogenesis influenced by the compartmentalization of its enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The activity of enzymes catalyzing the different steps in a metabolic pathway is regulated by compartmentalization of enzymes. Few enzymes of the pathway may be located in mitochondria and other few enzymes of the same pathway are in cytoplasmic. E.g: Heme synthesis, urea cycle and gluconeogenesis. The intermediates of the pathways are shuttled across the mitochondrial membrane for this purpose which provides a point where controls can be exerted.

  • • pathway

  • ➤ Gluconeogenesis is indeed regulated by the compartmentalization of its enzymes. This spatial organization allows for efficient control of the pathway, ensuring that enzymes necessary for gluconeogenesis are localized in specific areas of the cell, primarily within the mitochondria and cytoplasm of liver cells. This compartmentalization facilitates the regulation of enzyme activity and substrate availability, crucial for the maintenance of blood glucose levels, especially during fasting.

questions.text: A graph is presented depicting enzyme kinetics with and without an inhibitor. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows two lines intersecting on the y-axis. The line representing enzyme activity with an inhibitor has a different slope than that without an inhibitor, yet both lines intersect at the same point on the y-axis. Based on this information, what type of enzyme inhibition is being represented in this plot?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Competitive

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a Lineweaver-Burk plot , the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax , and the x-intercept represents −1/Km . In competitive inhibition :
  • • Lineweaver-Burk plot
  • • 1/Vmax
  • • −1/Km
  • • competitive inhibition
  • • The inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding at the active site . This leads to an increase in Km (i.e., substrate affinity appears reduced). However, since high substrate concentrations can outcompete the inhibitor, Vmax remains unchanged .
  • • The inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding at the active site .
  • • competes with the substrate
  • • active site
  • • This leads to an increase in Km (i.e., substrate affinity appears reduced).
  • • increase in Km
  • • However, since high substrate concentrations can outcompete the inhibitor, Vmax remains unchanged .
  • • outcompete
  • • Vmax remains unchanged
  • • Thus, in the Lineweaver-Burk plot , lines for inhibited and uninhibited enzyme intersect at the y-axis (same Vmax), but have different slopes due to increased Km — exactly as described in the question.
  • • Lineweaver-Burk plot
  • • y-axis
  • • different slopes
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B (Uncompetitive): In uncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex , decreasing both Km and Vmax . The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows parallel lines , not intersecting at the y-axis. Option C (Non-competitive): This affects Vmax (lowered) but not Km , and the plot shows lines intersecting on the x-axis , not y. Option D (Suicidal): Irreversible inhibition with no fixed pattern on the Lineweaver-Burk plot.
  • • Option B (Uncompetitive): In uncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex , decreasing both Km and Vmax . The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows parallel lines , not intersecting at the y-axis.
  • • Option B (Uncompetitive):
  • • only to the enzyme-substrate complex

questions.text: In a recent journal club meeting, a discussion arose around the adaptability of enzyme active sites upon substrate binding. questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the action of Disulfiram, a drug used in the treatment of alcoholism? Assertion(A): Disulfiram is used for treating alcoholism Reasoning(R): It inhibits the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase helps in alcohol avoidance:

options.label: A
options.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: A is right but R is a wrong statement

options.label: C
options.text: A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

options.label: D
options.text: A and R both are wrong

questions.correct_answer: B. A is right but R is a wrong statement
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A is right but R is a wrong statement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Assertion (A): True. Disulfiram is indeed used in the treatment of alcoholism as an aversion therapy drug. Reason (R): False. The mechanism of action of Disulfiram is NOT by inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase. Instead, it inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, the enzyme that converts acetaldehyde to acetate. As a result, after alcohol consumption, acetaldehyde accumulates in the body, leading to unpleasant symptoms (flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache), which discourages alcohol intake.
  • • Assertion (A): True. Disulfiram is indeed used in the treatment of alcoholism as an aversion therapy drug.
  • • Reason (R): False. The mechanism of action of Disulfiram is NOT by inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase. Instead, it inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, the enzyme that converts acetaldehyde to acetate. As a result, after alcohol consumption, acetaldehyde accumulates in the body, leading to unpleasant symptoms (flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache), which discourages alcohol intake.
  • • Thus:
  • • A is correct (Disulfiram is used for alcoholism), R is incorrect (wrong enzyme mentioned).
  • • A is correct (Disulfiram is used for alcoholism),
  • • R is incorrect (wrong enzyme mentioned).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A: Incorrect, because R is wrong. Option C. A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A: Incorrect, because R is false. Option D. A and R both are wrong : Incorrect, since A is true.
  • • Option A. A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A: Incorrect, because R is wrong.
  • • Option A. A and R both are right
  • • Option C. A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A: Incorrect, because R is false.
  • • Option C. A as well as R are right
  • • Option D. A and R both are wrong : Incorrect, since A is true.
  • • Option D. A and R both are wrong

questions.text: In cardiac diagnostics, clinicians often refer to the LDH isoenzyme ratio as an indicator of myocardial infarction (MI). In a typical healthy adult, the LDH-2 level is higher than LDH-1. A condition where this ratio is reversed, with LDH-1 being higher than LDH-2, is sometimes described in clinical practice. Is the term "flipped pattern" correctly applied to the scenario where LDH-2 is higher than LDH-1?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. False

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Healthy individual has LDH-2 higher than LDH-1. After certain types of myocardial injury, such as an MI, cardiac cells release more LDH-1 than LDH-2, which can lead to LDH-1 becoming higher than LDH-2. This reversal is what's referred to as a "flipped pattern," so the statement LDH-2 >>> LDH-1 being known as a flipped pattern is false.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question tests understanding of LDH isoenzyme patterns in normal and pathological states. The five LDH isoenzymes (LDH-1 through LDH-5) consist of different combinations of H (heart) and M (muscle) subunits. LDH-1 (H₄) predominates in heart tissue, LDH-5 (M₄) predominates in liver and skeletal muscle, and the others are hybrid forms. The normal serum pattern (LDH-2 > LDH-1) gets reversed in myocardial infarction, creating the "flipped pattern" (LDH-1 > LDH-2). While historically important, LDH isoenzyme analysis has been largely replaced by more specific cardiac markers such as troponin in modern clinical practice.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 69.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a key aspect of the active site of an enzyme?

This structural feature allows the active site to accommodate the substrate molecule (s) and exclude water , which is crucial for many enzymatic reactions.

The binding of the substrate to the active site is highly dependent on the precise alignment and orientation of specific amino acid residues and functional groups within the active site . This specificity ensures that only particular substrates can bind and be catalytically transformed by the enzyme.

Active site is situated in a crevice or cleft of the enzyme molecule. The substrate binds to the enzyme at the active site by noncovalent bonds and are hydrophobic in nature.   • • amount of substance
  • • Option C. Units: This term is often used in biochemistry , but it is not a standardized SI unit . One unit (U) is traditionally defined as the amount of enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of 1 micromole of substrate per minute, but it lacks the universal applicability and consistency of katals.

  • • used in biochemistry
  • • not a standardized SI unit
  • • Option D. Moles per second: While this could theoretically be used to describe enzyme activity , it is not the standard SI unit for this purpose. The katal is specifically defined as moles per second, making it the preferred and standardized term.

  • • describe enzyme activity

questions.text: In a groundbreaking study on enzyme diversity, scientists have discovered several enzymes within the same metabolic pathway that, despite differing structurally, perform identical functions across various tissues. This finding prompts a discussion on the classification of these enzymes. Which term accurately describes enzymes with different structures but the same catalytic function?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Allosteric enzymes : These are enzymes whose activity can be modulated by the binding of an effector molecule at a site other than the active site (allosteric site). The term "allosteric" does not imply that the enzymes have identical functions but different structures.
  • • Option A. Allosteric enzymes
  • • enzymes whose activity
  • • modulated by the binding
  • • effector molecule
  • • site other than the active site
  • • Option C. Coenzymes : Coenzymes are small, non-protein organic molecules that bind to enzymes and are required for their catalytic activity. They are not enzymes themselves and therefore cannot be classified as having the same catalytic function or different structures.
  • • Option C. Coenzymes
  • • small, non-protein organic molecules
  • • bind to enzymes
  • • required for their catalytic activity.
  • • Option D. Apoenzymes : An apoenzyme is the protein component of an enzyme, excluding any cofactors or prosthetic groups . It becomes an active enzyme (holoenzyme) upon binding with its cofactor. This term does not describe enzymes with different structures but identical functions.
  • • Option D. Apoenzymes
  • • apoenzyme
  • • protein component of an enzyme,
  • • excluding
  • • cofactors or prosthetic groups

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ISOENZYMES:
  • ➤ ISOENZYMES:
  • ➤ Different molecular forms of the same enzyme synthesized in various tissues are called isoenzymes. If the subunits are all the same , the protein is a homomultimer represented by a single gene. If the s ubunits are different, the protein is a heteromultimer , produced by different genes. They may be products of different genes (more than one locus) known as true isoenzymes . The genes may be located on different chromosome s, e.g. salivary and pancreatic amylase. In certain cases, all the different forms are present in the same individual, e.g. lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) has 5 isoenzymes and all are seen in all persons in the population.
  • ➤ Different molecular forms of the same enzyme synthesized in various tissues are called isoenzymes.
  • ➤ Different molecular forms
  • ➤ same enzyme synthesized
  • ➤ isoenzymes.
  • ➤ If the subunits are all the same , the protein is a homomultimer represented by a single gene.
  • ➤ subunits are all the same
  • ➤ homomultimer
  • ➤ single gene.
  • ➤ If the s ubunits are different, the protein is a heteromultimer , produced by different genes.
  • ➤ ubunits are different,
  • ➤ heteromultimer
  • ➤ different genes.
  • ➤ They may be products of different genes (more than one locus) known as true isoenzymes .
  • ➤ products of different genes
  • ➤ true isoenzymes
  • ➤ The genes may be located on different chromosome s, e.g. salivary and pancreatic amylase.

questions.text: A 35 year old man complains of fatigue and abdominal pain. O/E: Hepatomegaly + Laboratory results: Serum AST – 125 U/L, ALT – 82 U/L, ALP – 66 U/L, GGT– 170 U/L, Bilirubin – 1.0 mg/dL, glucose – 62 mg/dL, Uric acid – 8.0 mg/dL, CBC and urinalysis were normal. Which of the following markers help in monitoring alcoholism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Lactate dehydrogenase : While LDH levels can be elevated in liver disease , they are not specific for alcohol-related liver damage and can be elevated in a variety of conditions affecting the liver and other tissues.
  • • Option A. Lactate dehydrogenase
  • • LDH levels
  • • elevated in liver disease
  • • Option B. Glutamate hydrolase : Glutamate hydrolase (also known as glutaminase) is not a standard marker for alcoholism and is not typically used in this context.
  • • Option B. Glutamate hydrolase
  • • not a standard marker for alcoholism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carbohydrate Deficient Transferrin (CDT) is a specific biomarker for chronic alcohol consumption . Elevated levels of CDT in the blood can indicate excessive alcohol intake over a prolonged period . Unlike other liver function tests, CDT is less likely to be elevated due to non-alcohol-related liver diseases and thus serves as a more specific indicator of alcoholism.

questions.text: A 27-year-old biochemistry graduate student is presenting her findings on enzyme kinetics at a regional conference. She displays a Lineweaver-Burk plot as part of her presentation, highlighting the utility of this type of graph in determining enzyme kinetics constants. She points out the x-intercept and asks her audience to identify what this value corresponds to in terms of Michaelis-Menten kinetics. Which of the following is equal to the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Km​: This is incorrect because Km​ itself is not represented by the x-intercept ; rather, its negative reciprocal is.
  • • Option
  • • A. Km​:
  • • Km​
  • • not represented by the x-intercept
  • • Option C. Km​/Vmax​: This option is incorrect. While both Km​ and Vmax​ are parameters of the Michaelis-Menten equation , the ratio Km​/Vmax​ is not represented by the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot.
  • • Option
  • • C. Km​/Vmax​:
  • • Km​ and Vmax​ are parameters
  • • Michaelis-Menten equation
  • • Option D. 1/Vmax​: This is incorrect because the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax ​, not the x-intercept.
  • • Option
  • • D. 1/Vmax​:
  • • y-intercept represents 1/Vmax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ With “Double Reciprocal Plot” sometimes it is difficult to achieve high substrate concentrations to reach the maximal velocity conditions . So, ½ Vmax or Km is difficult to determine thus experimental data at lower concentrations is plotted as reciprocals a straight line is obtained when extrapolated to get the reciprocal of Km . This is called Lineweaver Burk Plot or Double Reciprocal Plot which can be derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation. If we plot 1/v against 1/[S], it will give a straight-line graph. X intercept is (-1/Km), from which the Km can be calculated.

This is called Lineweaver Burk Plot or Double Reciprocal Plot which can be derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation.
  • ➤ ½ Vmax
  • ➤ Km is difficult
  • ➤ experimental data at lower concentrations
  • ➤ reciprocals a straight line
  • ➤ extrapolated to get the reciprocal of Km
  • ➤ Lineweaver Burk Plot

questions.text: In an enzyme kinetics experiment, a substrate concentration 1000 times the Km value resulted in the conversion of 1% of the substrate into 12 µmol of product in 9 minutes with a certain enzyme amount. In a modified experiment, one-third of the initial enzyme amount is used with double the initial substrate concentration. How long would it take to produce the same amount (12 µmol) of product in the modified experiment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The reaction rate at or near Vmax is less affected by substrate concentration and more by enzyme concentration . Reducing enzyme to one-third decreases the rate to one-third , extending production time for 12 µmol of product to 27 minutes.
  • ➤ reaction rate at
  • ➤ near Vmax
  • ➤ less affected by substrate concentration
  • ➤ more by enzyme concentration
  • ➤ Reducing enzyme
  • ➤ one-third decreases the rate
  • ➤ one-third
  • ➤ production time for 12 µmol of product
  • ➤ 27 minutes.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper 30/e: p 76-79.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper 30/e: p 76-79.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker for the past 20 years presents with chest tightness and pain on the left upper limb for the past 14 hours. He is known hypertensive on regular antihypertensive medications and not a diabetic. ECG shows significant ST segment elevation in I, II and V1 to V6 leads. Laboratory investigations: Troponin T = 144 ng/ml (normal = <5 ng/ml) Troponin I = 250 ng/ml (normal = <0.04 ng/ml) CPK-Total = 2100 IU/L (normal = 40-300 IU/L) CPK-MB = 350 IU/L (normal = 5-25 IU/L) LDH = 343 IU/L (normal = 140-280 IU/L) AST = 745 IU/L (normal = 15-45 IU/L) Angiography revealed 96% block in the proximal portion of left anterior descending (LAD) artery. Which troponin is better for detection of MI?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Serum Troponin T (TnT) increases within 6 hrs of MI → peaks at 72 hours → remains elevated up to 10–14 days .
  • • Option A.
  • • Troponin T
  • • increases
  • • 6 hrs of MI
  • • peaks at 72 hours
  • • elevated up to 10–14 days
  • • Option C. Elevated cTn levels seen in acute coronary syndrome (ACS), stroke , pulmonary embolism , sepsis , acute perimyocarditis , acute heart failure and tachycardia . High sensitive TnT (hsTnT) has been developed, which detects even very low cTn concentrations.
  • • Option C.
  • • Elevated cTn
  • • acute coronary syndrome
  • • stroke
  • • pulmonary embolism
  • • sepsis
  • • acute perimyocarditis
  • • acute heart failure
  • • tachycardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Both Troponin T and Troponin I are cardiac-specific isoforms that are highly sensitive and specific for myocardial injury and are used as primary biomarkers for the diagnosis of MI . However, Troponin I is often preferred due to its higher specificity to cardiac tissue . There are several isoforms of Troponin I that are specific to cardiac muscle, and assays for Troponin I are designed to detect these specific forms, minimizing cross-reactivity with skeletal muscle.
